summary.title: OpenEMR Threat Model
summary.description: Threat modeling using OWASP Threat Dragon on the OpenEMR application.

data.name: Healthcare Provider
data.description: Clinical people who have access to and can manage patient records.

data.name: Patient
data.description: Those receiving medical treatment, if clinic uses the Patient Portal on OpenEMR.

data.name: Login
data.description: Clinical or patient individuals logging into OpenEMR.

threats.title: Attacker Logging In - stolen credentials, patient
threats.description: An attacker can pretend to be a patient logging into OpenEMR with stolen credentials - EoP Spoofing #8
threats.mitigation: Integrate Multi Factor Authorization (MFA) into login and lockout the account if there are too many login attempts detected.

threats.title: Attacker Logging In - stolen credentials, healthcare provider
threats.description: An attacker logs into a healthcare provider's account using stolen credentials where they can then perform further attacks on exposed patient records - EoP Spoofing #6
threats.mitigation: Implement and use digital certificates for user authentication that validates a user's identity; also log suspicious behavior such as logging in as a healthcare provider.

data.name: Access Records
data.description: Healthcare providers viewing or accessing patient records.

data.name: Messaging
data.description: If Patient Portal is activated, allows sending messages between healthcare providers and patients.

data.name: Excessive Messages
data.description: Sending an overwhelming amount of messages.

threats.title: Sending Excessive Messages
threats.description: An attacker can overwhelm the OpenEMR server by continuously sending excessive messages, or even using an automated "bot" to send hundreds of thousands of messages to overwhelm the system and cause DoS for users - EoP Denial of Service #4
threats.mitigation: Regulate or add CAPTCHA to prevent automated"bots" from sending messages. Introduce message rates to prevent manual sending of excessive messages.

threats.title: Altering Patient Records
threats.description: An attacker can look at patient records AND edit them maliciously from "the inside" - EoS Tampering #10
threats.mitigation: Configure the access control list (ACL) to be of role-based access, so that only verified users who have the particular role or "job" have access to such resources and behaviors on OpenEMR.

threats.title: Exposure of Patient Records
threats.description: An attacker can read sensitive patient records that only a healthcare provider and relevant patient should be able to read - EoS Information Disclosure #9
threats.mitigation: Introduce a better access control list (ACL) such as role-based and encrypt sensitive data that should not be read by "outsiders".

threats.title: Admin Changing Billing
threats.description: The admin of OpenEMR changes billing receipts to give special discounts to their friends or colleagues - EoP Tampering #10
threats.mitigation: Log behaviors and actions such as an admin changing billing for no apparent reason; also have billing changes be approved by another party apart from the admin.

threats.title: Attacker Causing Account Lockout
threats.description: The attacker knows that there exists an account lockout system that lockouts out an account that has multiple sign in attempts continuously, so the attacker brute force logs into the patient's account cause the patient to lose their account and experience a denial of service - EoP Denial of Service #10
threats.mitigation: Update the account lockout feature to be temporary (for a few minutes or up to an hour), so that the attacker's brute force attempts do not permanently lose the patient's account and data.

data.name: Edit Records
data.description: Healthcare providers updating lab results, records, notes, etc.

threats.title: Patient Edits Records
threats.description: A patient can update/change/edit their own medical records via an API they found and used - EoP Elevation of Privilege #4
threats.mitigation: Introduce a better access control list (ACL) such as role-based and encrypt sensitive data that should not be read by "outsiders".

data.name: Patient Database
data.description: Database of patient records, medical history, results, appointments, etc.

data.name: OpenEMR Logs
data.description: Official logging of information and behaviors/actions done on the OpenEMR application.

threats.title: Loss of Data from Logs
threats.description: An attacker can wrap around logs containing a sensitive attack they performed (such as logging in unauthenticated), and cause the logs  to be lost of the attack being done - EoP Repudiation #7
threats.mitigation: Automatically archive logs as they happen and before they are wrapped around or overwritten. Make the archive logs READ-ONLY to prevent log manipulation again.

data.name: Payment/Billing
data.description: Database of stored patient payment information and healthcare provider credentials for payment.

threats.title: Healthcare Personal Edits Billing
threats.description: A single healthcare worker such as a doctor or nurse edits or increases billing payment receipts for their customers (patients) in their advantage to make more money - EoP Tampering #10
threats.mitigation: Implement a better access control list (ACL) to something such as role-based access, so that users such as healthcare providers don't have the role or "job" to access the edit billing resource or function.
